humanum_full_description_en:
The original meaning of the word " corpse " has three meanings, one is that the elephant sits high (Li Xiaoding), as if sitting on a few feet; the other is that the elephant sits on the ground with knees bent (Shen Pei); the other is that the elephant sits on the ground (Xu Zhongshu). According to the first two, it is better.

The " sitting " of the ancients is equivalent to today's kneeling sitting , and compared to kneeling and squatting, the sitting posture with buttocks on the ground is more comfortable. When investigating ancient sacrifices, because the living could not bear to see the absence of their loved ones, they used the " corpse " of the living to represent the deceased to receive the sacrifices and even enjoy the sacrifices, such as "Ritual. "Shi Yu Li": "Scorpion Rice". The " corpse " is respected and treated preferentially, so let the corpse sit on a few knees or on the ground during the sacrifice. Because only a corpse can sit like this, the title of " corpse " is referred to in a sitting position.

In addition to sitting, the " corpse " must also stand. The ancient book has "Sit Dead" and "Sit Dead", as opposed to "Li Dead", "Book of Rites. "Ritual Instruments": "Zhou Zuzui", "Xia Lizu", "Yin Zuzui". "Baihutong": "Seat the corpse and eat it" means that the corpse is fed with a seat. The " seat " is a seat, and it seems that the " corpse " is like a person sitting on a stool.

The " corpse " can also refer to the "God Master Card" that represents the dead. In ancient times, "carrying the dead body to walk" refers to walking with the God Master Card (see "Historical Records-Guice Biography"). Later generations will still hold the "God Master Card" for sacrifice . The bamboo slips of the Warring States Period were added from " Shi " as the meaning sign, and " Shi " was like the god's main tablet. Note that this glyph was not used as the god's main card. See " show ".

The oracle bone inscriptions pretend to be " Yi ", Fang Guoming, "Compilation" 6459: "Zheng (Zheng) Corpse (Yi)", which means attacking the Yi side. It can also refer to human sacrifices from the corpse side, the Yi side. "Collection" 828: "Using ten corpses (barbarian) in the Ding, Mao and a cow." It means using ten animals from the barbarian side to sacrifice to the ancestor Ding and slaughter a cow. Bronze inscriptions are also pronounced as " barbarian ", meaning barbarians.ã¬Zhong: "The southern corpse (barbarian) and the eastern corpse (barbarian) are specific, twenty and six states."

Bronze " corpse " can also be used as a verb, meaning to play the role of " corpse " (a living person representing the dead). Yi Bogui: "The corpse is in the west palace", which means that the corpse serves as a corpse in the west palace. "poetry. Zhao Nan. "Collection": "Whoever owns the corpse, there is Qi Ji female." By extension, it can be interpreted as "holding" or "occupying" positions, such as "zombie", "zombie", "zombie vegetarian meal" and so on.

The bamboo slips of the Warring States period represent the living people who were sacrificed to the dead. Pingwang Asks Zhengshou" Brief 1: "The Temple of Corpses", that is, the "Temple of Corpses", emphasizing that it is a temple where " corpses " participate in sacrifices (Shen Pei).

Besides, in ancient times, apart from being the chief priest of the "corpse Zhu", there was also the custom of having the deceased's relatives act as the " corpse ", "Book of Rites. "Qu Li" has: "Sun can be the king's father's corpse" and "Yi Li. "Special Sacrifice Ceremony" note: "The corpse is the grandson of the sacrificed. The master of the ancestor's corpse is the son of the ancestor", etc., are all proof.

People nowadays generally think that " zo " is a simplified character for " zo ". It can be added that " zo " is originally a traditional Chinese character. The " zo " of corpse is represented by " zo " in ancient times. Later, "æ­»" was added as a sound symbol differentiation. A " corpse " refers specifically to the remains. See " corpse ".

"Said Wen": "A corpse, Chen Ye. It looks like a lying body. All corpses belong to the corpse."
humanum_short_description_en: The shape of a golden inscription sitting down on the knees. The original meaning is sitting. "The Analects. "Xiang Dang": "sleeping without a dead body", that is, not sitting while sleeping.

The original meaning of the word " corpse" has three meanings, one is that the elephant sits high (Li Xiaoding), as if sitting on a few feet; the other is that the elephant sits on the ground with knees bent (Shen Pei); the other is that the elephant sits on the ground (Xu Zhongshu). According to the first two, it is better. The " sitting" of the ancients is equivalent to today's kneeling sitting, and compared to kneeling and squatting, the sitting posture with buttocks on the ground is more comfortable. When investigating ancient sacrifices, because the living could not bear to see the absence of their loved ones, they used the " corpse" of the living to represent the deceased to receive the sacrifices and even enjoy the sacrifices, such as "Ritual. "Shi Yu Li": "Scorpion Rice". The " corpse" is respected and treated preferentially, so let the corpse sit on a few knees or on the ground during the sacrifice. Because only a corpse can sit like this, the title of " corpse" is referred to in a sitting position. In addition to sitting, the " corpse" must also stand. The ancient book has "Sit Dead" and "Sit Dead", as opposed to "Li Dead", "Book of Rites. "Ritual Instruments": "Zhou Zuzui", "Xia Lizu", "Yin Zuzui". "Baihutong": "Seat the corpse and eat it" means that the corpse is fed with a seat. The " seat" is a seat, and it seems that the " corpse" is like a person sitting on a stool. The " corpse" can also refer to the "God Master Card" that represents the dead. In ancient times, "carrying the dead body to walk" refers to walking with the God Master Card (see "Historical Records-Guice Biography"). Later generations will still hold the "God Master Card" for sacrifice . The bamboo slips of the Warring States Period were added from " Shi" as the meaning sign, and " Shi" was like the god's main tablet. Note that this glyph was not used as the god's main card. See " show". The oracle bone inscriptions pretend to be " Yi", Fang Guoming, "Compilation" 6459: "Zheng (Zheng) Corpse (Yi)", which means attacking the Yi side. It can also refer to human sacrifices from the corpse side, the Yi side. "Collection" 828: "Using ten corpses (barbarian) in the Ding, Mao and a cow." It means using ten animals from the barbarian side to sacrifice to the ancestor Ding and slaughter a cow. Bronze inscriptions are also pronounced as " barbarian", meaning barbarians.ã¬Zhong: "The southern corpse (barbarian) and the eastern corpse (barbarian) are specific, twenty and six states." Bronze " corpse" can also be used as a verb, meaning to play the role of " corpse" (a living person representing the dead). Yi Bogui: "The corpse is in the west palace", which means that the corpse serves as a corpse in the west palace. "poetry. Zhao Nan. "Collection": "Whoever owns the corpse, there is Qi Ji female." By extension, it can be interpreted as "holding" or "occupying" positions, such as "zombie", "zombie", "zombie vegetarian meal" and so on. The bamboo slips of the Warring States period represent the living people who were sacrificed to the dead. Pingwang Asks Zhengshou" Brief 1: "The Temple of Corpses", that is, the "Temple of Corpses", emphasizing that it is a temple where " corpses" participate in sacrifices (Shen Pei). Besides, in ancient times, apart from being the chief priest of the "corpse Zhu", there was also the custom of having the deceased's relatives act as the " corpse", "Book of Rites. "Qu Li" has: "Sun can be the king's father's corpse" and "Yi Li. "Special Sacrifice Ceremony" note: "The corpse is the grandson of the sacrificed. The master of the ancestor's corpse is the son of the ancestor", etc., are all proof. People nowadays generally think that " zo" is a simplified character for " zo". It can be added that " zo" is originally a traditional Chinese character. The " zo" of corpse is represented by " zo" in ancient times. Later, " æ­»" was added as a sound symbol differentiation. A " corpse" refers specifically to the remains. See " corpse". "Said Wen": "A corpse, Chen Ye. It looks like a lying body. All corpses belong to the corpse."

["Guangyun" style fat cut, flat fat, book. ]
(1) People who were sacrificed to the deceased in the ancient ritual era.
(2) God's main card is made of wood.
(3) Establish a statue of a god or a god master.
(4) Assume; undertake.
(5) Presiding; taking charge.
(6) The main body.
(7) Said to be in the position and do nothing.
(8) To enjoy; to live.
(9) Corpse.
(10) Said to be like a corpse.
(11) Said that the corpse is shown to the public.
(12) Collect the corpse.
(13) Stretch.
(14) Literary words.
(15) Through "barbarian".
(16) Last name. The corpse of the Warring States is outstanding.
